source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The zirconium tetrachloride was purified by dissolving it in a molten-salt bath, then pumping the resulting salt mixture into a vaporizer, where the tetrachloride was vaporized and then condensed in another vessel.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Filtered liquid sodium and solid zirconium tetrachloride were metered into a continuous reactor where $\mathbf { Z r C l } _ { 2 }$ and NaCl were formed at a temperature of about $2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 3 9 2 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The pots were then placed in floor furnaces and heated to several hundred degrees, at which point the second reduction reaction proceeded to reduce the $\mathbf { Z r C l } _ { 2 }$ to metallic zirconium, exothermically raising the temperature of the pot to a red heat.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: After several hours of soaking, the pots were removed from the furnace, allowed to cool, and then opened.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: A jackhammer was used to break the reaction mass and salt out of the pot, after which the mass was crushed to $6 \ \mathrm { m m } \ ( 0 . 2 5 \ \mathrm { i n } )$ size and leached with water.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: However, after leaching, the sponge still contained about $1 / _ { 2 } \%$ NaCl and some sodium; hence, it would not meet AEC specifications.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The sponge was compacted into an electrode and fed through an induction coil in an inert atmosphere, and the molten zirconium was allowed to drip on to a rotating disk.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: At first, "platelets" about I in. $( 2 . 5 4 \mathrm { c m } )$ in diameter were formed by this process, but these were difficult to compact into consumable electrodes for arc melting.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Finally, the melting rate was speeded up so that "chunklets" were formed, and these proved highly satisfactory.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: In fact, they had an advantage over the crushed sponge in the conventional Kroll process in that they were easier to handle and were not pyrophoric.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The plant, which has a capacity of 1.36 to 1.81 million $\mathbf { k } \mathbf { g }$ (3 to 4 million lb) of zirconium sponge per year, is completely integrated from zircon sand to finished mill products such as strip and extruded tube hollows.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircon is chlorinated at $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ $1 8 3 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ in fluidized-bed chlorinators equipped with fluidized-bed condensers.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The methylisobutyl ketone (MIBK)- thiocyanate solvent extraction process is used to separate hafnium.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The zirconium is precipitated as pentazirconyl sulfate and calcined directly to the oxide.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The hafnium-free zirconium dioxide $( Z \mathbf { r } \mathbf { O } _ { 2 } )$ is then chlorinated to $\mathsf { Z r C l } _ { 4 }$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Reduction of the tetrachloride with magnesium takes place in 152-cm-diameter (60-in.) integral-type retorts to produce 1134 to $1 3 6 1 \mathrm { k g }$ (2500 to 3000 lb) of sponge per batch.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: First-melt electrodes $4 5 . 7 \mathrm { c m }$ (18 in.) in diameter are melted to $5 5 . 9 \mathrm { c m }$ (22 in.) in diameter and remelted to $6 3 . 5 – \mathsf { c m }$ -diameter (25- in.) $5 4 4 5 \mathrm { - k g }$ (12000 lb) second-melt electrodes.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Mixtures of zircon sand and carbon can be chlorinated in fluidized beds to form $\mathbf { Z r C l _ { 4 } }$ and $\ S i C l _ { 4 }$ , and this method has been used in recent years to produce most of the zirconium tetrachloride used in the United States.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: This reaction is endothermic and requires temperatures of $1 1 5 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ $( 2 1 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ and above to obtain reasonable production rates.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Complete utilization of the chlorine is claimed to occur when the operating temperature is kept between 1200 and $1 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ (2192 and $2 3 7 2 \mathrm { ^ \circ F }$ ), provided that a specified minimal bed depth is maintained.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Density of the condensed tetrachloride is dependent on the concentration of tetrachloride in the gas stream, the gas temperature and flow rate, and the wall temperature of the condenser.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: it should be possible to produce a hard spherical tetrachloride particle with a bulk density as high as $2 4 0 0 \mathrm { k g / m ^ { 3 } } ( 1 5 0 \mathrm { l b / f t ^ { 3 } } )$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: The other method that has been used commercially to open the ore is a caustic fusion process in which the zircon is reacted with sodium hydroxide in steel pots at 600 to $6 5 0 \mathrm { { ‰} }$ (1112 to $1 2 0 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ to form a frit.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: the sodium zirconate can be dissolved in sulfuric acid $\mathrm { ( H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { S } \mathbf { O } _ { 4 } )$ hydrochloric acid (HCl), or nitric acid $\left( \mathrm { H N O } _ { 3 } \right)$ to provide whatever solution is required for further processing.

conditions.medium: sulfuric acid, hydrochloric acid, nitric acid

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: the major application of zirconium as a structural material in nuclear reactor cores demands that the hafnium content be reduced to below 100 ppm and, for some applications, below 50 ppm.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: the thermal neutron absorption cross section of hafnium at 105 barns is almost 600 times as great as that of zirconium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: the need to also produce a hafnium product with a zirconium content of $2 \%$ or less.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: The aqueous zirconium raffinate is diluted to a zirconium content of about $_ { 1 2 \mathrm { ~ g ~ } }$ /litre (0.1 lb/gal)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: Zirconium is extracted from the feed liquor with a 50% solution of tributyl phosphate in n-heptane

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: solvent previously equilibrated with 8-M HNO3

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: Hafnium and impurities are back-scrubbed with HNO3

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: The solvent is scrubbed with deionized water to recover the zirconium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: Both metal product streams are distilled to recover free nitric acid, and neutralized to precipitate the hydrates, which are then calcined to the oxides

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: TBP-nitric acid process is capable of producing a high-purity zirconium product with low hafnium content

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: production of a hafnium product with low zirconium content is reported to be difficult

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: Kim and Spink at Waterloo University... patented a method to separate HfCl4 from ZrCl4 in a molten-salt solution by a distillation technique at 101.3–kPa (1 atm) pressure

conditions.medium: molten eutectic of zirconium tetrachloride, sodium chloride, and potassium chloride

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: crude zirconium tetrachloride is selectively reduced by zirconium or zirconium dichloride at 420°C (788°F)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: hafnium tetrachloride and any unreacted zirconium tetrachloride can be sublimed away at 200 to 300°C (392 to 572°F) in a vacuum

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: These vapors may contain up to 30% hafnium tetrachloride

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: Upon heating above 450°C (842°F) the zirconium trichloride will disproportionate to mixed dichloride and tetrachloride

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: The hafnium content of this tetrachloride will be about 0.5% (500 ppm)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8
